student_data.notes: Undergraduate and Total Graduate counts sourced directly from UCSB Engineering Facts & Figures (Fall 2023). The university does not explicitly publish a live split of MS vs PhD enrollment on the summary page. PhD/MS counts are estimated based on the 'Degrees Awarded 2022-23' data (69 MS, 29 PhD) and estimated program durations (2 years MS, 5.5 years PhD). Estimated Steady State: (69*2)=138 MS, (29*5.5)=160 PhD. Total estimated pool ~298. Scaling this ratio to the actual 321 enrolled students results in ~149 MS and ~172 PhD. [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

gpu_resources.notes:
Data derived from UCSB Center for Scientific Computing 'Pod' cluster documentation.

CALCULATIONS:
- A100 80GB: Nodes gpu-[29-32] (4 nodes x 4 GPUs) + Nodes gpu-[37-40] (4 nodes x 4 GPUs) = 16 + 16 = 32 GPUs.
- A100 40GB: Nodes gpu-[23-28] (6 nodes x 2 GPUs) = 12 GPUs.
- A40: Nodes gpu-[33-36] (4 nodes x 4 GPUs) = 16 GPUs.
- V100 (32GB): Nodes gpu-[0-16] (17 nodes x 2 GPUs) + Nodes gpu-[17-21] (5 nodes x 2 GPUs) + Node gpu-22 (1 node x 4 GPUs) = 34 + 10 + 4 = 48 GPUs.

Note: Older clusters (Knot) are legacy/deprecated and not included in active high-performance counts. [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

analysis_notes: UCSB centralized GPU resources are managed by the Center for Scientific Computing (CSC). The 'Pod' cluster is the primary resource. Student counts are well-documented by the College of Engineering, though the specific MS/PhD split required estimation based on graduation data.
